Definition.WordDefinition:
motivation \motivation\ n. 1. The act or process of motivating. [PJC]
2. The mental process that arouses an organism to action; as, a large part of a teacher's job is to give students the motivation to learn on their own.
Syn: motive, need. [WordNet 1.5 +PJC]
3. The goal or mental image of a goal that creates a motivation[2]; as, the image of a peaceful world is a powerful motivation for only a rare few individuals. [PJC]

Definition.WordDefinition:
Motivate \Mo"ti*vate\, v. t. [imp. & p. p. {-vated}; p. pr. & vb. n. {-vating}.] [From {Motive}, n.] To provide with a motive; to move; impel; induce; incite. -- {Mo`ti*va"tion}, n. --William James.
Syn: move, prompt, incite, induce impel, drive. [Webster 1913 Suppl.]

motivation n 1: the psychological feature that arouses an organism to action toward a desired goal; the reason for the action; that which gives purpose and direction to behavior; "we did not understand his motivation"; "he acted with the best of motives" [syn: {motive}, {need}] 2: the condition of being motivated; "his motivation was at a high level" 3: the act of motivating; providing incentive [syn: {motivating}]
